bibl.title: Letter from Ralph Cooper Hutchison to Philip Showalter Hench, March 4, 1937

div1.p: Hutchison informs Hench that Lord Dawson cannot attend the Founders' Day ceremonies. He is considering postponing the event until commencement and again inviting Dawson, as this would also give them more time to prepare the “Yellow Jack” performance.

div1.head: Letter from Ralph Cooper Hutchison to Philip Showalter Hench, March 4, 1937

opener.dateline:
THE PRESIDENT'S OFFICE
WASHINGTON AND JEFFERSON COLLEGE
WASHINGTON, PENNSYLVANIA
March 4, 1937

div1.p:
I have not been in a hurry to write
this letter because you are off in Florida and it
will be some time before you are back. I am
disappointed to pass on the word to you that Lord
Dawson cannot come. I do not know what this will
do to our plan and whether or not we shall find an
effective substitute, or rather change the whole
proposition. My general feeling about the matter is
that the best plan would be to postpone it to
Commencement next year and try again for Lord Dawson.
This will be a little better in regard to the play,
“Yellow Jack,” which is too difficult to work up in
the short season coming before Founders' Day. It
could be in good shape before Commencement, however.

I will not write more now because this
letter will be cold before you see it, but I hope
that you and Mary will have had one grand time in
Florida.
div1.closer:
Affectionately yours, Hutch Dr. Philip S. Hench
Mayo Clinic
Rochester, Minnesota
